frontmatter.title: Analyzing Salinity Patterns in South Florida

affiliations.name: NSF National Center for Atmospheric Research

children.value: This notebook demonstrates how to analyze salinity patterns in South Florida using curated buoy data processed by the
, a high-performance file system interface for the Open Science Data Federation (OSDF).

The data used here comes from three monitoring stations managed by FIU, each located in a distinct part of South Floridaâ€™s coastal waters. These datasets were curated and made analysis-ready by the EnviStor pipeline.
What are the salinity patterns in South Florida?
Weâ€™ll answer this by loading the data, cleaning and merging it, and visualizing salinity trends over time across multiple locations.

import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

from pelicanfs.core import OSDFFileSystem
from io import BytesIO

sns.set(style="whitegrid")
Weâ€™ll load data from three buoy stations directly from PelicanFS using the
interface. These Excel files have already been curated and prepared by the EnviStor smart pipeline, and are stored in the
Each file corresponds to a different buoy location:
to read the content as a stream before passing it to
column to identify its source location.

pelfs = OSDFFileSystem()
file_buoy1 = pelfs.cat('/envistor/CREST_Buoy_2_NW_Biscayne_Bay_-_S_of_Biscayne_Canal_082720-112221.xlsx')
file_buoy2 = pelfs.cat('/envistor/CREST_Buoy_3_Haulover_Inlet_100518_-_073020_updated.xlsx')
file_buoy3 = pelfs.cat('/envistor/CREST_Buoy_3-2_Little_River_042121-050624.xlsx')

excel_file1 = BytesIO(file_buoy1)
df_file_buoy1 = pd.read_excel(excel_file1)
df_file_buoy1['Station'] = 'Buoy - Biscayne Bay'

excel_file2 = BytesIO(file_buoy2)
df_file_buoy2 = pd.read_excel(excel_file2)
df_file_buoy2['Station'] = 'Buoy - Haulover Inlet'

excel_file3 = BytesIO(file_buoy3)
df_file_buoy3 = pd.read_excel(excel_file3)
df_file_buoy3['Station'] = 'Little River'

children.value: Now that weâ€™ve loaded the individual DataFrames, weâ€™ll prepare them for analysis.
and convert its values to numeric (in case of string or error-prone entries).
: Concatenate the three cleaned DataFrames into one (
) so we can analyze salinity trends across all buoy stations together. We also drop any rows with missing salinity values and set the
column as the index to enable time-based operations later.

for df in [df_file_buoy1, df_file_buoy2, df_file_buoy3]:
    df["datetime"] = pd.to_datetime(df["Date"].astype(str) + " " + df["Time"].astype(str))

    df.rename(columns={"Sal_psu": "Salinity"}, inplace=True)
    df["Salinity"] = pd.to_numeric(df["Salinity"], errors="coerce")

df_all = pd.concat([df_file_buoy1, df_file_buoy2, df_file_buoy3], ignore_index=True)
df_all.dropna(subset=["Salinity"], inplace=True)
df_all.set_index("datetime", inplace=True)
Salinity readings are taken multiple times per day. To reveal broader trends, we resample the data to
Makes it easier to compare across time
We group by station and resample by day (
Now we can plot daily salinity patterns to compare how they evolve over time across the three locations.
Weâ€™ll use Seaborn for a clean, readable line chart.

plt.figure(figsize=(14, 6))
sns.lineplot(data=df_daily, x="datetime", y="Salinity", hue="Station")
plt.title("Daily Average Salinity in South Florida (by Buoy Station)")
plt.xlabel("Date")
plt.ylabel("Salinity (psu)")
plt.legend(title="Station")
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()
This visualization is only possible thanks to the
, which curated, cleaned, and enriched the buoy data, and published it to OSDF.
allowed us to access the data on-demand using
â€” no local downloads or manual data wrangling required. This is a great example of how data infrastructure can directly support scientific insight.
With the visualization in hand, we can start identifying key salinity patterns in South Florida:
, with higher salinity in dry months and noticeable drops likely linked to storm events or freshwater inflow.
levels, suggesting stronger tidal mixing and less influence from freshwater discharge.
â€” sharp dips and spikes in salinity hint at frequent freshwater input, possibly from canals, rain events, or upstream runoff.
impact salinity levels. By comparing trends across stations, we gain insight into how dynamic and localized coastal salinity can be.
This type of analysis can support environmental monitoring, resource management, and research on saltwater intrusion and estuarine health.
This notebook provided a foundation for analyzing coastal salinity patterns using curated data from the EnviStor pipeline. If youâ€™re interested in extending this work, here are a few ideas:
: Analyze how temperature, turbidity, or dissolved oxygen vary alongside salinity to build a more holistic view of water quality.
: Use GIS tools or libraries (e.g., Cartopy or Folium) to visualize station locations and explore spatial gradients in salinity.
: Investigate long-term salinity trends and identify anomalies across different seasons or years.
: Expand the workflow by pulling additional datasets from OSDF, such as ocean currents, rainfall, or metadata-enriched observations.
: Identify salinity levels that may signal ecological stress or risk, potentially integrating this with decision-making tools.
Curious about how the data got so clean? Check out the
role in preparing these files â€” from metadata tagging to anomaly filtering â€” to better understand the power of backend automation.
